tealights right and most of the time that's fine usually you can find
multiple colors or whatever but sometimes you can you're also limited by
the size of the components so a little bit there you have your restricted by
what you're able to find I'm going to show you how to design your own circuits
and build your own custom lighting rigs I'm going to teach you a little bit
about electrical theory as long as you know basic algebra you'll be able to
follow this I promise so you'll learn that you'll be able to
design your own circuits within an hour or two and then I'm going to show you
how to use the digit key website digi-key is one of several excellent
online suppliers of components I'm going to show you how to go in and search for
the right part it can be daunting if you don't know what you're doing because
there's literally hundreds of thousands of parts in inventory so I'm gonna show
you how to whittle down and know what you're looking for know what's important
and what's not and show you how to design source your parts and solder up
your own custom lighting very excited about this episode I've been working on
it for about eight months now an engineer by background so very excited
about it let's get to it
we begin with the fundamental equation that voltage equals current times
resistance this is called Ohm's law voltage represented by V is a
measurement of electrical potential between two points the higher the
voltage between two points the greater the difference in charge between those
two points as an analogy consider a glass of water if you drill a hole at
the bottom you'll get a stream of water coming out but if we've make that glass
50 feet tall fill it up and drill the same hole in the same spot you'll get a
much higher flow rate but before the holes are drilled the water is just
sitting there in either case so for this analogy the
very tall glass has a higher voltage a higher potential so voltage is how we
quantify potential and it has units of volts current represented by I is a
measurement of actual electric flow back to our analogy the water flow from the
first glass would be a fairly low current the water flow from the very
tall glass would be a high current current is how we quantify the flow of
electricity itself and it has units of amperes resistance represented by R is a
measurement of the opposition to the flow of electricity again to our analogy
we drilled a hole in the glass right but what if we drilled a larger hole well
over any given time more water would be flowing than if it were a smaller hole
and that's true for the normal glass and the very tall glass so resistance is how
we quantify the opposition to the flow of electricity and it has units of ohms
so here's a basic circuit about as basic as you can get it has a voltage source
in this case a 9-volt battery and it has a switch which right now is open if we
close the switch electric current will begin to flow in the direction you see
here from the positive terminal of the source to the negative terminal of the
source but how much current well right now the circuit has no devices in it it
has no resistance so if we apply Ohm's law 9 divided by zero gives us infinity
of course there isn't infinite current all
materials including the wire in the circuit have some amount of electric
resistance but in a common wire it's near zero it's negligible so the point
is with nothing to resist the current this battery it's gonna max out we call
this a short circuit because it has no loads it usually means some portion of
the circuit is going to be damaged so we can put devices in our circuit to
receive the power and offer resistance the very simplest one is called a
resistor here's what a common resistor looks like notice that it has two leads
on it which you would use to solder it in place
resistors do not have polarity so you can attach them either way let's insert
a 40 ohm resistor into our circuit now we have a controlled current nine volts
divided by 40 ohms equals 0.2 - five amps or 225 milliamps but what if we
create another link in the circuit like this with 45 ohm resistor this
arrangement is called in parallel in a parallel circuit the voltage across each
branch is the same in other words between the two blue points you have a
difference of nine volts and between the two red points you also have a
difference of nine volts this makes calculating the behavior of
each branch very easy the current of the new branch is nine divided by 45 which
is 200 milliamps that means that the total current for the entire circuit is
225 plus 200 which is 425 milliamps the more current there is the shorter the
battery life now here's those two resistors again but arranged in series
instead of parallel the math governing a series circuit is different than a
parallel circuit I'm not going to go into it because we're not going to use
it for our custom lighting and I wanted to keep this tutorial as simple and
focused as possible but if you're interested just google something like
series versus parallel circuits now let's add some devices to our
circuit specifically LEDs an LED is a light emitting diode which means that it
only permits current to flow in one direction in other words they do have
polarity and so they do need to be soldered into the circuit in the correct
orientation they also have a zero or near zero resistance
so as we calculate our circuits overall current we don't need to care about them
however LEDs are interesting in that they do require a certain amount of
voltage to begin emitting light which is called the forward voltage
I'm not going to delve into detail here as to what this is because you don't
really need to understand it to be able to build these simple circuits but let's
simply say that LEDs sort of leach some of the voltage in order to gather enough
power to actually begin lighting up and the amount leached is called the forward
voltage so when you use Ohm's law to calculate the current going through an
LED you need to adjust the V term specifically you need to subtract the
forward voltage from the source voltage the result is what the LED will actually
experience we're going to step through that mathematically later on
step-by-step but for now just remember that the forward voltage of the LED is
an important thing so where do we begin well first consider the type of project
you're doing if for example it's a torch in the sconce
well then a nine volt battery is office we're not going to work you'd need a
small coin battery that can be hidden easily perhaps in the circular base of
the Scott's but if you're doing a large set piece that'll have dozens of LEDs

topic on theory which is probably not going to be relevant to you unless
you're designing big circuits or using big batteries like a 9-volt power is
defined as current times voltage and it has units of watts all components can
only handle certain amount of power going through them and so we say that
they are rated for a given wattage let's look at the green LED branch of our
circuit there's 20 milliamps going through this branch right so the power
is 3 volts times point 0 2 amps which is point 0 6 watts now look back at the
resistor we bought for it you can see right there in the description that it's

minuscule compared to what it's rated for but if there was more than 5 watts
flowing through the circuit you would want to find a different resistor one
that is obviously rated for higher than it will experience and in fact if you

the parts power rating right soldering soldering is not a daunting thing you
can buy a basic soldering iron kit and a set of tips and a spool of solder for
around 20 dollars here's one I found on Amazon without even trying and while
you're at it by some connecting wire a higher gauge means a thinner wire high
gauge is fine does not need to be fancy here's an example a soldering iron gets
extremely hot and it melts solder that flows onto
in order to create an electrical connection solder is sold on spools like
this it's a very soft metal the key to making a good solder connection is
tinning your leads this means coat the things you want to
join together with solder individually first then touch them together and
briefly apply the soldering iron again they'll quickly melt flow together and
cool in other words don't just take two bare ends and try to hold them together
while also applying solder tin them individually first it's easier and it
gives a better quality connection in a future episode we're gonna make a power

that tiny 45 on one is rated for only a quarter watt the bigger one is more able
